Reviews.Title: Not the typical junky chinese stuff
Reviews.Author: Mike S.

logTag.type = "text/javascript"; logTag.src = "/gp/customer-media/du/log.html?ie=UTF8&p=CustomerImage&s=CustomerVideoPlay"; head[0].appendChild(logTag); } if (cv_mo1KCQVEEEP31KLcurrentClick) { return cv_mo1KCQVEEEP31KLcurrentClick(); } } } Length:: 0:04 MinsI'd like to smack the designers in the noggin, because focusing this surprisingly well made chinese camera gave me a headache.Mine came with a tiny CD and a quick start guide and installation screws and those usually useless plastic screw-in thingies and a template. It has a tiny fan, but there's no heater. If you can hear that little fan outside then your hearing is Superman quality. I changed the cable routing from the rear to the side. It was kinda scary at first, but it only took around 15 minutes to do. This is my third Dahua camera. There's no marking on the camera fwiw. Oh.. The discovery (camera ip 192.168.1.108 with user/password: admin/admin) cd software was in a strange z format. View [...] for related Dahua software. I'd like to give it 4.5 stars, because focusing it really is a pita and warranty support/firmware upgrades are unlikely in the future. Version Device Type IPC-HDBW3300 Software Version 2.103.0000.0.R, build : 2012-07-24 WEB Version 3.0.0.0 - My camera has W-IPV5300 printed on the box, but HDBW3300 printed on the circuit board. The lens is 3.3 -12 mm. The back plate is screwed into the main body with three (3) allen headed screws. Four (4) phillips head screws (I think) attach the backplate to its mounting location. Three allen headed (3) screws attach the plastic dome to the waterproof body. The zoom and focus screws are the small straight driver type. A Phillips head screw secures the dome to the body.

Reviews.Title: Initial impression:  This thing is a tank, well built, has lots of features
Reviews.Author: YeahSoMaybe? "computersandmusicperson"
Reviews.Content: Received this yesterday.  This Dahua 3MP is a tank - it's easily 2X the size of my other (i.e. Hikvision) 3MP camera.  I plugged in indoors and it gives a good detailed picture.  Will do more testing in the coming week.SIZE:*  This camera  is * NOT * discreet.  There is nothing dainty about this camera physically.  In it's own way it's as big as some of the older skool bullet security cameras.  Your security fashion statement is: " I'm  ** WATCHING ** you YOU WEASELS!!!  You  ** ARE ** on camera and I'm PARANOID!! ...Make NO Mistake!"  For perspective:  I would say it's bigger than my Q-see 720P bullet cameras.*  Unusual features:  I * believe * it has a built in microphone and speaker.  It also has what appears to be a tamper alarm cable.  And a old skool (If you wanted it) DC power input.  There is no shortage of I/O cables on this camera.*  It can hold a 32GB SD card but I've always been puzzled as to who does that.  I intend to mount this thing up high under an outdoor eve and stream surveillance to a Windows 7 Pro PC (3TB size drive) running Foscam Blue IRIS.  That PC will dedicated to two particular high megapixel output cameras.*  Q-SEE USERS - SOME GOOD NEWS:  For a quick test, I plugged this into an open port on my Q-SEE 816 NVR (Network Video Recorder).  It was found (discovered)on the Q-SEE NVR and delivering a decent picture to it's monitor within 30 seconds.*  It's solidly built.  Outer housing appears to be all metal.  The actual dome may be Lexan or something like it.  I think the dome might survive one or more good slingshot hits from a rock or ball bearing.  You might have a cracked dome but the camera has a good chance of survival.  And what kind of idiot sticks around to attack a security camera?  ( I know.. I  know.. you'd be surprised).*  It even has one of those metal "knockouts" (screw port a little bit larger than a nickel) for a true, conduit type, serious install.I'll have more to report when I do the full install in the coming week.  Over and out.

Reviews.Title: Way too expensive for less features than expected.
Reviews.Author: K.R. "K.R."
Reviews.Content: I purchased 2 of these after having loved the other version which we now prefer hands down (Dahua IPC-HFW4300S 3MP HD Network Security Camera - 1080p Outdoor Indoor Small IR Bullet IP CCTV Camera).PROSJust like its sister product (Dahua IPC-HFW4300S 3MP HD Network Security Camera) it has a great web interface, but it lacks what the cheaper sister product has in video controls on the web control panel.CONS- TOO EXPENSIVE. This thing is a tank, and we were expecting an easy way to move this dome camera remotely around, forget about it. You have to use screws inside the tank to move anything around, and then they tell you to focus the lens that can go out of focus using another screw inside (all the while on a ladder 50 ft in the air?). Yes we could have done a test on the ground, which we did, but to move it where we wanted it to point, etc. For the price, this is in no way different or any better than the less expensive but a few more featured (Dahua IPC-HFW4300S 3MP HD Network Security Camera).For a complete review of this product, see our review on the (Dahua IPC-HFW4300S 3MP HD Network Security Camera) as it has the same features as that camera, but we prefer it over this expensive tank hands down.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera for the price.
Reviews.Author: powmaster
Reviews.Content: Nice picture but beware, the format is 4x3 and not widescreen (16x9) at max resolution. I have another Dahua and they are nice cameras for the price. Easy installation and setup, but then I have experience from other Dahua IP cameras. One suggestion, Buy the BlueIris camera software. Well worth the $47 price. And no, I don't work or sell Blueiris software, but really like it.

ProductInfo.Features:
3-Megapixel
1080P ONVIF
Infrared Dome IP Camera
3.3-12mm Auto-Iris
25m IR, 12v/24v, PoE, IP66, D-WDR
ProductInfo.Name: Dahua IPC-HDBW3300 3MP (3 Megapixel) Color IP Network Security Camera, HD 1080p (2048Hx1536V) Resolution, Day/Night mode
